ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Music 475 was a very intimate, explorative, and educational experience. Professor Kreuzer was extremely professional and inspiring, and the conversation in our small seminar was always engaging. Kreuzer did a fantastic job structuring the course, and the time that she put into the students and the material, in turn, inspired us to put forth our best work. A wonderful senior seminar to take for music majors.

This seminar was very deliberately tied to the centenaries in 2013, so it is unlikely to be offered again, which is a pity, because it was a phenomenal course. The papers were a bit rough, but Kreuzer is an excellent seminar leader: Brilliant, enthusiastic, and encouraging, this was honestly the best seminar I have taken in my time at Yale. If you have _any_ interest in opera, find a course that Kreuzer is teaching and TAKE IT!

Verdi, Wagner, Britten in 2013 is a senior seminar in the Music Department. In this course, you will study the commemoration of these composers at their anniversaries as well as take in-depth looks at musical examples. If you can take any class with Professor Kreuzer, do so!
An open-ended survey into some great composers, with special focus on their current-day impact. Very useful for a greater appreciation of old music in our lives.
